Description: Body fragment with turn to rim of Laconian black-figured pottery kylix; dull cream slip; interior: black-figure decoration consisting of part of horse to left in the exergue (belly with added red, genitals, left foreleg, hind legs with red, and tail in red remaining); around, pomegranate frieze; at junction with rim black band; exterior: at rim and body junction, narrow black band; in handle zone horizontal handle palmette with red heart; below, frieze of short rays between sets of narrow and broad bands, the latter with added red.
Curator's comments: The sherd belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1888,0601.526.l and 1888,0601.526.k. This sherd has been attributed to the Hephaistos Painter, who has been renamed the Boreads Painter (Lane 1933-1934, 131, no 12). The kylix has also been attributed to the Arkesilas Painter (Shefton 1954, 300, no. 9).
The simple pomegranate pattern around the tondo is particular to the Boreads Painter.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B7.4.10)
